technology.short_description: Some mounts are disobedient and others are just plain dangerous, so it's sometimes necessary to "put a bit of stick about" to keep them in line and focused on the task at hand.
All that riding makes one a bit "sensitive and hurty", but this miracle substance, made from the bile leftover from certain types of dinner, works wonders, and in no time.
The only forms of currency Ogres will accept are food and gold. When many tribes are working together, agreeing on a standard is vital if healthy relations are to be maintained.

effects.description: Income from sacking and looting settlements: +25%

technology.short_description: Gnoblar Trappers delight in tormenting smaller animals and following Ogre Hunters into battle. Baiting them beforehand ensures that only the fastest, most intrepid candidates may attend.

effects.description: [hidden] Used to increase rank for Hunters from camps in conjunction with regular effect (with different scopes)
Speed: +20% for Gnoblar Trappers and Hobgoblins units

technology.short_description: Eating crushed limestone reduces cases of 'Ogre Breath' enough so the Ogres can stand closer together and fight in ranks.

effects.description: Recruit rank: +2 for Ogre Bulls units

technology.short_description: Though it tends to lead to gut-aches and even-more-chronic flatulence than usual, there's sense in depriving the enemy of supplies, so they have to fight you in a weakened state.
Winding sinew around weapon handles makes for better grip, which in turn makes them easier to wield.

effects.description: Weapon strength: +10% for Ogre Bulls units
Charge bonus: +10 for Ogre Bulls units

technology.short_description: It's important to discuss payment from the outset to prevent things going south at a later juncture.
Understanding that the Tyrant's tribute must be paid, no matter how well things went, is essential if you want to carry on living.
A portion of payment extracted for services rendered to others is always sent home. It's just respectful.
All the better for smashing the foe to bits with.
A larger campsite means more groupings of tents, and therefore more Ogres gathered in one place – multiplying the threat level many times over.
Those pathetic, snivelling Gnoblars can be leashed and made to sniff out the best loot, and more of it too.

effects.description: Recruit rank: +2 for Gnoblars and Hobgoblins units

technology.short_description: Once you get a handle on the local food supply, things start to come together quite well, quite quickly, regardless of how far the Ogres are from home.

effects.description: Camp growth: +20 when in enemy territory

technology.short_description: Now the whole camp can eat together – bringing a bit of decorum to proceedings, you might say. Almost.

effects.description: Control: -4 in enemy provinces where an army is present

technology.short_description: Even Ogres know that keeping records of agreements can avoid the more violent forms of disagreement further down the track; simply sign your name with an 'X'.
Gorgers like their meat raw or recently slaughtered, so the best kind of bait is the kind that's still wriggling.

effects.description: Casualty replenishment rate: +10% for Gorgers and Ogre Hungerers units
Recruitment cost: -10% for Gorgers and Ogre Hungerers units
Weapon strength: +20% for Gorgers and Ogre Hungerers units

technology.short_description: Every last ounce must be scoured from the bones. Nothing should be wasted.
After a while spent trapping for a Hunter, a Gnoblar Trapper develops a sense – as well as a nose – for their prey.
Determining the best place to set up camp? It's a process of elimination.
Iron makes teeth better, so they cause more damage. Obviously.

effects.description: Weapon strength: +10% for Sabretusk Pack, Stonehorn, Gorgers, Ogre Hungerers and Giant units

technology.short_description: At the heart of every camp lies the Mawtooth stone. The Ogres will fight harder, and with every last breath and ounce of strength, to ensure it is protected.

effects.description:
Melee defence: +15%
	(own armies factionwide in enemy territory)

technology.short_description: A couple of Ogres having a conflab quickly becomes a huddle as more and more gather around them.
When several smaller Ogre camps become large enough and touch, a bigger gathering – a throng – is formed.
It's a bit fiddly, but some Ogres have a natural affinity for such things, and are able to make tents big enough to house a huddle or more.
Here, all the Ogres of the tribe sit together in one place to eat and make plans (chiefly, to eat even more).

attributes.bullet_text: This unit can cause terror, making its melee target rout for a short time. Units that cause terror are immune to terror and fear themselves.

technology.short_description: Signalling that the several tribes that make up an Ogre kingdom are on the move, as a single, brutish, hungry horde.
These enormous, woolly beasts are notoriously dense, even by Ogre standards, and therefore require a bit of 'encouragement' in the breeding department.
Believe it or not, it's not always possible to eat all the available meat in one go, so it's necessary to develop preservation techniques if you don't want to see good food go to waste.

effects.description: Upkeep: -25% for Gnoblars, Hobgoblins and Gnoblar Scraplauncher units

technology.short_description: As it turns out, many of the Ogres' natural prey are a bit thick and can be tricked into giving up their lives without expending too much effort.
Get the lads some more meat and grog or I'll bash you again! We'z fightin' soon, and it ain't easy runnin' uphill at those cowards when you weigh ova a thousan' kilos.

related_attributes.bullet_text: Speed and combat penalties caused by terrain are ignored by this unit.

effects.description:
Passive ability: "Exceptional Offensive"
	(own armies factionwide in enemy territory)

technology.short_description: Sharper weapons do more damage, something many Ogres learn from watching their Butcher at work.

effects.description: Melee attack: +4 for Ogre Bulls units

technology.short_description: Whatever it is he's using to flavour the meat makes it taste nicer, and has some healing properties too.
The bigger the spit, the bigger the meal, the more satisfied the diners.
Keep 'em hungry, keep 'em mean.
"The Firebellies are comin' – time for a feast! Who's for some flametoad and devilpepper curry?"

effects.description: [hidden] Used to increase rank for Firebellies from camps in conjunction with regular effect (with different scopes)

technology.short_description: This meat's well past its best, but hardy Ogre constitutions can probably still handle it. The price reflects this.
The Maneaters have spent their long lives accumulating wealth abroad on campaign as mercenaries for foreign powers, which has given them a nose for the best plunder.

effects.description: Melee defence: +5 for Gnoblars and Hobgoblins units

technology.short_description: The natural musk of a mighty Mournfang, bizarrely, will attract other animals – ones you want to trap, kill and bung on a spit over the fire with haste.

effects.description: Recruit rank: +2 for Mournfang Cavalry units

technology.short_description: This one's not much of a talker, but more of an imposing presence who cracks his knuckles a lot, which speaks volumes to his opposite numbers.
Scrolls appropriated from Cathay have revealed their deadly secrets…

effects.description: Reload time reduction: +10% for Ironblaster units

technology.short_description: Gold is useful for opening ears to new ideas.
A bigger pit allows for more meat to be cooked at one time, so many mouths can be fed in a single sitting.
"Somefing could 'appen, yer know? You wouldn't wan' there to be an 'accident', now would yer?"
The volcanic peak kills many when it erupts, so making sure the Fire Mouth gods are appeased should be high on any self-respecting leader's list of things to do.
Applying Warpstone to steaks before cooking them keeps the number of mutations down.

effects.description: Attrition: -50% casualties suffered from Chaos Undivided corruption and Chaos Wastes attrition
Attrition: -25% casualties suffered from all attrition

technology.short_description: Simply promising not to eat the foreign envoys puts trade negotiations on a better footing from the outset.

effects.description: Income from trade: +5% for every ally

technology.short_description: As the Tyrant's super-hard elite guard, Ironguts naturally get the best armour and weapons available to the tribe.

effects.description: Leadership: +5 for Gnoblars and Hobgoblins units

technology.short_description: The megalithic defences of this long-gone race were built into the mountains themselves. It's not completely beyond the Ogres to work out how to use them, but almost.

effects.description:
Defensive supplies: +500 per turn when under siege
	(all regions factionwide)

technology.short_description: If you hit, throw and generally abuse them enough, Gnoblars occasionally have good ideas – in this instance, a Rhinox-drawn scoop for picking up all the scrap.

effects.description: Upkeep: -50% for Gnoblars, Hobgoblins and Gnoblar Scraplauncher units
Recruitment cost: -50% for Gnoblars and Hobgoblins units

technology.short_description: Some hungry Ogre souls were born to serve the Great Maw.

effects.description: Campaign movement range: -10% for enemy armies starting their turn in your regions

technology.short_description: Recipes and spells are scrawled upon the aprons of the Slaughtermasters and Butchers, steeping them in magic and causing them to absorb even more of the stuff.

effects.description: Winds of Magic power reserve change: +20% when increasing

technology.short_description: The long-abandoned fortresses of the, rarely, if ever-assailed Sky-Titans make ideal campsites for the brighter Ogre tribes.

effects.description: Camp limit: +1 for every level 5 camp built

technology.short_description: The higher the piles of riches around the Mawtooth, the more brutally the ogres are willing to defend it.
Some of the more clever shamans have discovered certain additives that provide the camp's denizens an edge in combat.
Following the primal instincts of the ferocious beasts they keep in their camps, the Ogres adapt savage combat strategies.
